ratings.comment: His lectures are pretty confusing, but every now and then he would make a little math joke and that's why he's not a 1. Definitely check if there's a better prof out there, but if he's your only option, he's not completely terrible. Definitely be prepared to watch a lot of Khan academy.

Professor Bolotin is an okay professor, but he never made me understand the material clearly. The lectures were hard to sit through but he would crack a joke every once in a while. This class just was not for me.

From what I've heard, one of the better calc 3 profs. Nice guy, doesn't take himself too seriously, and his accent is not too hard to understand. Lectures were pretty clear but I found taking my own notes on the textbook more helpful than going to them. Exam questions and grading were fair. A good TA is important if you haven't taken calc 3 before.

The class itself was fairly brutal. 20% of the grade was 2 midterms, and 40% was the final. Dr. Bolotin was knowledgeable about the material. The lectures were very proof heavy so students knew why they were doing it, but they were never on the exams. Overall, the course material was difficult, but it was doable.

Bolotin is a great professor who builds upon the textbook using examples (often from homework due later that week) to solidify understanding. He does proofs in class, but the tests aren't proof-based. The final exam is worth 40%. Exam grading is very clear. You quickly get used to his Russian accent. The homework load is extremely manageable.

Sergei is a good-natured, seemingly reserved fellow whose puns may go over your head until you get used to his light accent. He is a professor that clearly understands how calculus should be taught to less experienced audiences. Pay attention during lecture and you will learn the intuitive reasoning behind the way Calc 3s challenges are solved.

The class is proof heavy, the accent is hard to understand at times, not the most organized person, prone to making mistakes, the tests were hard but that's more on me, but Sergey seems like a nice guy. However I don't think he's the right professor for me.

At first, his ascent might be confusing but not a problem later. His is generally teaching faster than other instructors at the begining of the semester since chapter 16 is really hard and he use lots of time on it. His exams are super easy. If you know the basic, you can do the exams.

Sergey's lectures can sometimes be boring, especially when he starts talking about proofs. Nonetheless, his explanation is very clear and easy to understand. Also, he is hilarious! His exams are way easier than the homework and discussion problems. If you understand how to do the old exams, you will get an easy A.

Professor Bolotin is a down to earth man and knows how to crack a joke now and then. He teaches the content in a concise manner and sometimes includes proofs. His lectures are dense but helpful, and if you need additional help, take advantage of office hours because he is always willing to help outside of lecture. His exams are nothing too bad.
Not a bad guy. While his lectures were somewhat boring, the midterms and final were straight forward. If you do your homework and maybe do a few problems of his practice tests, you will do just fine!

Lectures are a little dry and hard to follow but in class examples were pretty applicable. A good TA really helps. Exams were fair and if you did the in class worksheets, quizzes, and past exams you'll be fine.
Very lecture heavy! You get to use a notecard on midterms which is very nice. His accent is thick but very easy to get used to. Very funny, kind, verrryyy cute old man.
Don't worry about the accent. He likes to lecture with proofs. Only two midterms so study hard for those.

Class is super easy if you pay attention in lecture and work in groups on homework assignments. If you put in the effort, you'll do fine. Also, go to his office hours!! Not many people go but they are sooooo helpful.

Thick accent makes him hard to understand at times. Lectures are very proof heavy. Better pray you get a good TA to help you out. The tests were very difficult for me, but that's probably just the nature of the course.
Calculus classes are usually pretty challenging. I would say this is not the hardest one to sit through, but Sergey isn't the most exciting person to listen to during a power lecture.

Idk why people thinks of him poorly, I personally feel his examples are much more applied than theoretical in math 234. Examples he gives in class a lot of times are related to physics,  which is pretty fun. Plus you don't have to understand physics. He uses his own notation and problem solving style which I think is much better than the textbook

Probably the least memorable professor I've had--and that's not necessarily a bad thing. He just kind of showed up and did his thing for 50 minutes and left every day. Taught very heavily with proofs so most of the actual learning is done in discussion. Has an accent but is easy to understand.
Thick accent, lectures aren't always organized the best. You get used to it though.
Sergey did a good job lecturing for this course. He was very good about letting you know what you needed to know for the tests. The class was difficult just because it's calc three.
Sergey is good at teaching 234. He keeps it simple and is very fair with what he asks on tests and homework. If you have a hard time understanding him, move closer.

I would definitely recommend Sergey as a professor! He doesn't always explain concepts thoroughly and wasn't very accessible outside of class, but generally does a good job of teaching the material and his exams are very fair. Also, his accent isn't bad at all.
Overall a solid instructor. Sometimes spends too much times on proofs, but all in all a solid choice compared to the other 234 professors this fall.

He is a good professor and sets straight forward tests. Calc 3 is itself a challenging course so you have to  make sure that you are on top of your work to get a good grade. He has a clear grading criteria. Would recommend him.
Do not take this professor. He sucks at teaching and spends half his lecture teaching proofs which aren't even on the tests.

Where's the love for Sergey? I loved having him as a freshman for Math 221, and tried having him again for Math 320.  I did not regret my decision.  Sergey's english had gotten better, he's funnier, and he seemed more enthusiastic in his teaching.  Exams weren't too difficult, but do well in discussion (65% quiz averages) , and it's an easy A!

The homework? No clue if I did it right. The lectures? Learn your letters and numbers in Russian. The tests? Not the worst. But you won't know your grade for the whole of the semester. Just pray for a good grade when your final grade gets posted. Put your hands in the air and let Jesus take the wheel.

Should attend lecture to do well, but he only goes over textbook problems during lecture. Lectures are extremely boring and he sometimes forgets what he's doing and just writes the answer. Not very helpful if you ask him questions. Have to go to discussion, TAs can be helpful. Tests get  harder as course progresses, but gives partial credit.
Not a good teacher. Very lost, long pointless proofs during lectures and impossible exams.

Sergey is not very clear and difficult to understand. 222 is a hard class as it is, but I had a hard time understanding what he was doing during lecture because of how he teaches. He does a lot of examples in lecture but doesn't really explain them. I would recommend reading the textbook on your own.

Sergey does a lot of confusing proofs and skips a lot of steps when solving problems on the board, which can lead to a really confused class. I caught myself falling asleep more than a handful of times near the end of his lectures, but to his credit math is hard to make interesting. He was always very clear about what will be on tests.

An extremely hard class taught by a professor with a very thick Russian accent. I took calculus BC the year before, and it is was still very difficult. Sergey is quirky and funny, but most of the time the lectures are not helpful. Proofs, proofs, and more proofs are his forte. I would recommend a supplement textbook to accompany the one given.
Very nice guy. As a math major, I think his proof helps me a lot.

I don't think he's a bad professor, calculus is just a tough subject. My only complaint about him is he told us he doesn't know econ and business and fall 2015 was the first time he taught business calc. Therefore, he didn't do as much applied business calc as I wished for. He has an accent but after a few lectures it's fine. But overall, not bad.

He always said what topics weren't going to be on the exams, so you knew what you didn't have to worry about.  Tests were pretty fair for the most part, no super trick questions.  Calc is still calc though, so don't expect something easy.  Lectures were boring since he really did nothing but proofs, but when he got to examples, those were helpful.
Proofs.  Lots and lots of proofs.  Nothing but proofs

Lectures were pretty boring, but then again it is math. If you have a solid foundation from high school you can skip lecture and only go to discussion. Tests are very straightforward and he never puts "trick" questions in.

As far as professors go, Bolotin is a fine one for calculus I. Lots of people seem to complain that the information is not explained well and that Bolotin writes "useless" proofs about the material during lecture. However, I thought that the proofs given were helpful in concept visualization and that Bolotin did a fine job explaining basic calculus

Teaches straight from the book. Many people chose to skip lecture and learn from discussion. There's homework every week which usually takes an hour or two to complete so not terrible on that front. He collects homework on test weeks though which is rough. Also there's online homework. Overall, not a great professor but he tries and is a nice guy.
Material covered in class is nowhere near as hard as the tests -- be warned!
